channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Trump’s advisers, rather than dwell on shaky economic data, have painted a rosy outlook for next year
item.description: Advisers are privately assuring the president that his policies will pay off.
item.dc:creator: Josh Dawsey

item.title: Many government leaders have had the chance to voice opposition to President Trump’s tariffs inside the White House. The mayor of Pohang, in South Korea, is the rare official who can say he has protested outside it
item.description: Like Pittsburgh, the South Korean city of Pohang is synonymous with steelmaking. Its struggling local industry has been hit hard by U.S. levies.
item.dc:creator: Soobin Kim

item.title: Federal-Worker Buyouts Are Kicking In, Darkening the U.S. Employment Picture
item.description: About 100,000 federal workers came off the payroll last week, adding strain to an already weakening labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Focus on Fed Minutes, U.S. Shutdown Developments
item.description: Focus in the coming week will center on any developments with the U.S. government shutdown. Wednesday’s minutes for the last Federal Reserve meeting will attract a good deal of attention.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires staff

item.title: U.S. Services-Sector Activity Unexpectedly Stagnates
item.description: The ISM’s purchasing managers index for services providers fell to 50.0 in September from 52.0 in August. Economists expected it would remain at the same level of expansion.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Unboxing the thrill of Labubus, or why so many young consumers are spending big on blind boxes
item.description: Getting hold of Labubus and other blind-box toys is a game of odds; the thrill of the surprise keeps young consumers coming back for more.
item.dc:creator: Audrey Valbuena

item.title: The monthly jobs numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics won’t arrive on time because of the government shutdown. But private firms are helping fill the gap.
item.description: The monthly government jobs numbers didn’t arrive on time. But private firms are helping fill the gap.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Bank of Japan Still on Path to More Rate Hikes, Governor Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan remains committed to further interest-rate increases, Gov. Kazuo Ueda said, amid growing speculation over the timing of the central bank’s next move.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Swiss Inflation Holds Steady Close to Zero
item.description: Consumer prices were 0.2% higher in September than in the same month of last year, matching the rate of inflation in August.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump’s tariff rollout has taken numerous twists and turns since launching earlier this year. Here’s a roundup of where things stand.
item.description: A roundup of where things stand with tariffs on key U.S. trade partners and sectors.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham

item.title: Bank of Canada Cut Rates Despite Uncertainty On Inflation Outlook, Minutes Say
item.description: Senior Bank of Canada officials believed a rate cut was warranted even though upside risks to inflation remained intact, according to minutes published by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: The U.S. shed 32,000 private-sector jobs in September, payroll processing giant ADP said
item.description: The ADP private-sector jobs report showed a labor force that continues to deteriorate.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: India’s Central Bank Stands Pat Amid Tariff Pressures
item.description: India’s central bank kept its policy rate unchanged as U.S. tariffs continued to cloud the South Asian economy’s outlook, while signaling that it remains open to further easing.
item.dc:creator: Kimberley Kao

item.title: Taiwan Pushes Back on Idea of Shifting More Chip Production to U.S.
item.description: Taiwan’s top trade representative has pushed back on the idea that the island will shift more of its chip production to the U.S. as the tariff tug-of-war continues.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Picks Up Pace as ECB Looks Set to Keep Rates on Hold
item.description: European Central Bank rate setters are sanguine about potential pressures on prices and expect last month’s rise in inflation to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: South Korea’s Exports Jumped in September, Beating Expectations
item.description: Semiconductor shipments, which account for roughly one-fifth of the country’s total goods exports, surged to a monthly record.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: Morgan Stanley’s Stress Capital Buffer Revised Lower
item.description: The Federal Reserve is reducing Morgan Stanley’s stress capital buffer to 4.3% after the bank asked it to reconsider its rating.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Hamilton

item.title: BOE Deputy Governor Sees Inflation Resuming Fall After ‘Hump’
item.description: The recent pickup in inflation, which is projected to hit 4% this month before declining, is unlikely to have long-lasting consequences, said Sarah Breeden.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Labor-Turnover Was Steady in August
item.description: The rate of layoffs in the economy was mostly steady at 1.1% from July. Hiring was largely steady as well, with the rate of new job offers holding at 3.2%.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Inflation Risks Are ‘Contained’
item.description: Eurozone inflation is unlikely to rise much above, or fall much below, the European Central Bank’s target despite a reshaping of global trade, President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Continued to Cool Ahead of Fed’s Rate Cut
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.7% in the 12 months through July, down from 1.9% on year in June and continuing a run of the weakest price rises since July 2023.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Heard on the Street: Problems in the for-sale housing market are starting to infect the rental business
item.description: Problems in the for-sale housing market are starting to infect the rental business.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Tariffs, Uncertainty to Slow Asia’s Economic Growth, ADB Says
item.description: Asia’s economies grew at a solid pace in the first half, but that momentum will slow as tariffs take effect, the Asian Development Bank said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: BOE Has Scope for Careful and Gradual Rate Cuts, Says Ramsden
item.description: The Bank of England can continue to lower its key interest rate while bringing inflation down to its 2% target, deputy governor Dave Ramsden said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: A new barrier for foreign workers could open some opportunities for U.S. tech workers, who for months have faced a dismal job market. But many aren’t expecting much help.
item.description: Many say their biggest problems are a weak domestic job market, the rise of AI and a glut of displaced people looking for similar roles.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Ellis

item.title: President Trump announced many new tariffs Thursday, including a large one on pharmaceutical companies that aren’t building plants in the U.S.
item.description: Levies on drugs will be imposed on companies that aren’t building plants in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: Sales of existing homes dipped in August, after high prices kept sales in check
item.description: The median home price rose to $422,600, up 2% from a year ago and the highest price ever for the month of August.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: In the week through Sept. 20, jobless claims filings declined to 218,000 from 232,000 the week before. Economists polled were forecasting 235,000 claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The U.S. and global economies are set to slow less sharply this year than previously expected, but will continue to lose momentum in 2026, the OECD said
item.description: Global economies will continue to lose momentum as higher tariffs take a large toll on activity, the research body said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: With the Fed in cutting mode, many people expect mortgage rates to fall fast. Unfortunately, it isn’t that simple.
item.description: While the Federal Reserve has begun cutting rates again, there are many other factors that affect the cost of home loans.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Housing Starts Declined More Than Expected in August
item.description: Home-building slumped last month, as mortgage rates remained high and amid an uncertain environment for building-materials prices.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Census Bureau data show that average U.S. households haven’t gained ground economically since the Covid-19 pandemic struck
item.description: High-income households fared better than others, while women lost ground to men, according to Census Bureau data.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending
item.description: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending.
item.dc:creator: Alison Sider

item.title: German Consumers Feel Ever Gloomier as Economy Slumps
item.description: Concerns around unemployment drove the cautious mood among German shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Consumers Sunnier as BOE Cuts Rates But Economic Fears Remain
item.description: U.K. consumers felt a little better about their finances this month as the Bank of England lowered borrowing costs, though sentiment remains weak amid wider economic turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Anxious shoppers, concerned about inflation and their personal finances, are cutting their spending to focus on essentials
item.description: Generic brands and bulk buying are on the rise as shoppers find themselves in a summer of economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan
